newsitem.title: UK: PRESS DIGEST - Financial Times - May 8.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Financial Times - May 8.

text.p: Prepared for Reuters by The Broadcast Monitoring Company
ICI PAYS 4.9 BILLION STERLING FOR UNILEVER ARM

The UK's Imperial Chemical Industries has made plans to purchase the specialty chemicals division of Unilever for 4.9 billion sterling and sell three billion of its own chemicals businesses. ICI chairman Robert Hampel said the purchase finalised the "complete transformation" of the company and has announced plans to reduce its interest in its Tioxide subsidiary. It has now been four years since ICI's pharmaceuticals businesses were demerged as Zeneca.
GEC, BAE AND DASA BACK BIDS IN THOMSON AUCTION

New entrants into the auction for French state-controlled defense electronics company Thomson include General Electric Company, British Aerospace, and Daimler-Benz Aerospace. The move of support came following the submission of final bids by Alcatel and Lagardere to the French government, as the foreign companies realised Thomson's fate is crucial to the restructuring of the European defense electronics sector.
CATERING GO-SLOW LEAVES BA MENUS UP IN THE AIR

Non-first class passengers on 30 British Airways flights from Heathrow airport on Wednesday were denied meals on their flight due to a go-slow by BA catering staff. The passengers were instead given restaurant vouchers, advised to pack sandwiches or eat at the airport prior to their flight's departure and a 12 hour flight to San Francisco had to be cancelled. BA catering staff are working, but refusing to work overtime, upset over the announcement that the in-flight catering operation at Heathrow was being put up for sale.
FIRST TEST OF COMPETITION ON RAILWAYS COMING UP

UK rail companies South Wales & West and Virgin Cross Country are battling over the launch of new train services on the newly privatised railway. VCC currently runs trains between Penzance and Manchester and from Portsmouth to Liverpool, but SW&W may be given permission to operate on the same routes if UK rail regulator John Swift decides to allow the move and increase competition. Swift had imposed restrictions on new services which compete with existing trains until March 1999, with other controls to allow then companies to become established.
BP CHIEF TO SERVE IN TWO DEPARTMENTS

Sir David Simon, who is about to leave British Petroleum to work for the government's Emu and labour practices campaigns on the continent, has been appointed to serve in both the Treasury and Department of Trade and Industry. He will now sit in on all cabinet committees on Europe and the economy and will chair a taskforce to promote competitiveness in Europe. Prime Minister Tony Blair also announced that Simon would be given a peerage.
PRIVATE BUYERS BOOST CAR SALES

Registrations of new cars in the UK rose 12.3 per cent in April, leading to speculation that total new car sales for the year could come close to matching the record 2.3 million mark reached in 1989. A total of 182,747 registrations were made, bringing the 1997 total to 732,281 and the chief executive of the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said that the trend should continue 'in spite of interest rate changes'.
SHOWCASE POWER STATION PLANNED

The UK's second largest power generator, PowerGen, has announced it will team with Siemens of Germany to invest 150 million sterling into a centre for testing and demonstrating combined cycle gas turbine technology. The proposed plant, named Cottam Development Centre, will use gas power to drive secondary turbines and will replace Siemens' current facilities in Berlin.
DALGETY SLASHES DIVIDEND

UK petfood and agribusiness group Dalgety is set to cut its dividend by one-third after a warning that the strong pound and BSE would lower its second half profits below the 43 million sterling market reached in the first half. The group announced a provisions figure of 36 million sterling to cut pet food manufacturing costs and the strength of sterling has led to the loss of about eight million sterling from this year's profits, expected now to be in the area of 80 to 85 million sterling
NEW SMALL TOYOTA MAY BE BUILT AT EUROPEAN PLANT

The president of Toyota has announced that it may begin production in 2001 at a European plant of 'a completely new kind of small car for the European market'. The official announcement will be made in 1998, and current possible locations for the manufacture include Derbyshire in the UK. The car maker would be required to spend approximately 300 million sterling with European component suppliers, with the component-makers who supply the Burnaston plant as the central beneficiaries.
BSKYB SIGNS INTERACTIVE TV PROVIDERS

It was revealed on Wednesday that UK satellite television venture, British Sky Broadcasting has been working with about 30 organisations to develop interactive services for its new digital satellite project. The different organisations ranged from financial services to travel and retail groups and included HMV, J Sainsbury and Great Universal Stores. BSkyB also announced confirmed orders of one million digital satellite decoders from Amstrad, Pace Micro Technology and Matsushita and Hyundai.
